description: Get started with Django, a high-level Python web framework

slides.title: What is Django?
slides.content:
# What is Django? ðŸŽ¸

Django is a high-level Python web framework that encourages rapid development and clean, pragmatic design. It was created by a team of developers at a newspaper in Kansas (Lawrence Journal-World) to meet tight deadlines.

## Key Characteristics:
- **"Batteries Included"**: It comes with everything you need (ORM, Auth, Admin, etc.) so you don't have to reinvent the wheel.
- **Open Source**: Free and open to the public.
- **Secure**: Built-in protection against common attacks like SQL injection and XSS.

> ðŸŽ¯ **Fun Fact**: Django is named after the famous jazz guitarist **Django Reinhardt**!

slides.title: Advantages of Django
slides.content:
# Why Choose Django? ðŸš€

## 1. Speed ðŸŽï¸
Django was designed to help developers take applications from concept to completion as quickly as possible.

## 2. Security ðŸ›¡ï¸
Django takes security seriously. It provides tools to easily avoid common security mistakes, such as:
- **Cross-site scripting (XSS)**
- **Cross-site request forgery (CSRF)**
- **SQL injection**

## 3. Scalability ðŸ“ˆ
Django uses a "shared-nothing" architecture, meaning you can add hardware at any level (web servers, database servers, caching servers) to handle massive traffic. Giants like **Instagram** and **Pinterest** use Django!

slides.title: Installing Django
slides.content:
# Installing Django ðŸ“¦

To install Django, you usually do it inside a **Virtual Environment** to avoid conflicts with other projects.

## Step 1: Create Virtual Env
```bash
# Mac/Linux
python3 -m venv myenv

# Windows
python -m venv myenv
```

## Step 2: Activate It
```bash
# Mac/Linux
source myenv/bin/activate

# Windows
myenv\Scripts\activate
```

## Step 3: Install Django
```bash
pip install django
```

## Step 4: Verify
```bash
python -m django --version
```

slides.title: Django Project Structure
slides.content:
# Project Structure ðŸ—ï¸

When you run `django-admin startproject mysite`, Django creates specific files.

```text
mysite/
    manage.py        # Command-line utility
    mysite/
        __init__.py  # Tells Python this is a package
        settings.py  # Configuration (DB, apps, etc.)
        urls.py      # URL declarations (Table of Contents)
        asgi.py      # Entry point for ASGI (Async)
        wsgi.py      # Entry point for WSGI (Deploy)
```

> âš ï¸ **Important**: `manage.py` is your best friend! You'll use it for running the server, making migrations, and creating apps.

slides.title: The MTV Pattern
slides.content:
# Model-Template-View (MTV) ðŸ›ï¸

Django follows the MTV pattern, which is similar to MVC (Model-View-Controller).

| Component | Responsibility |
|-----------|----------------|
| **Model** | The data layer. Handles database structure and queries. |
| **Template**| The presentation layer (HTML). How the user sees data. |
| **View** | The business logic. Fetches data from Model and passes it to Template. |

> ðŸ’¡ **Analogy**: 
> - **Model**: The Chef (cooks raw ingredients)
> - **View**: The Waiter (takes order, gets food from chef)
> - **Template**: The Menu/Plate (how food is presented)

slides.title: Creating an App
slides.content:
# Projects vs. Apps ðŸ§©

- **Project**: The whole website (e.g., A social network).
- **App**: A functional module inside the project (e.g., The timeline, the chat, the authentication system).

## Creating an App
```bash
python manage.py startapp polls
```

This creates a `polls` directory with:
- `models.py` (Database tables)
- `views.py` (Logic)
- `apps.py` (App config)
- `admin.py` (Admin panel config)
- `tests.py` (Testing)

> ðŸ’¡ **Tip**: Don't forget to add your new app to `INSTALLED_APPS` in `settings.py`!
